attributes.title: Supervision of Designated Safeguarding Leads in primary schools
attributes.description: This randomised controlled trial aims to establish the impact of providing supervision to Designated Safeguarding Leads in primary schools in Bolton.

q1.value: Evaluation of supervision of Designated Safeguarding Leads in primary schools

q3.value:
Designated Safeguarding Leads (DSLs) are the members of staff in a school who have the lead responsibility for safeguarding and child protection, including responsibility for referring cases that meet threshold levels of concern on to Children’s Social Care. The role involves having to make difficult decisions about complex situations and vulnerable children, however DSLs tend not to receive adequate formal supervision.

This programme aims to test the impact of providing formal, individual supervision to DSLs in primary schools, with the aim of reducing inappropriate contacts to children's social care.

In total, 94 primary schools in Bolton Council are eligible to participate in the programme, and will be randomly assigned to either receiving the intervention, or support as usual. The DSLs allocated to the intervention group will receive monthly supervision, provided by an experienced social work manager over the course of six months. The primary outcome measure will be the proportion of contacts made to CSC resulting in no further action.

q4.value:
The primary research question this evaluation is designed to answer is: 
1) What is the effect of providing support to DSLs in primary schools on the proportion of pupils for whom a contact is made which does not lead to a social care referral (i.e. no further action at contact)? 

The evaluation will also address the following research questions:
2) What is the effect of providing support to DSLs in primary schools on the proportion of pupils for whom an Early Help Plan is submitted? 
3) What is the effect of providing support to DSLs in primary schools on the proportion of pupils for whom a new referral is made? 
4) What is the effect of providing support to DSLs in primary schools on the proportion of pupils for whom a new referral results in a Child in Need Assessment (section 17 start)?
5) What is the effect of providing support to DSLs in primary schools on the proportion of pupils for whom a new referral results in a Child Protection enquiry (section 47 start)? 
6) What is the effect of providing support to DSLs in primary schools on the proportion of pupils for whom a new referral leads to a child becoming a Looked After Child?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Two-armed cluster randomised trial, involving around 94 primary schools in Bolton. Randomisation takes place at school level with approximately half of primary schools being allocated to the treatment group (receiving the support of the designated social work manager) and half to the control group (who do not receive this support).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The analysis will make use of data that are being collected by Bolton Council (based on administrative data that are routinely collected by the local authority). The analysis will be conducted by the evaluation team; the data for analysis will only be passed to the evaluation team once analysis is ready to commence.

question.value: Primary schools located within Bolton local authority are eligible to participate. Schools have been identified by Bolton Council. A small number of schools are not eligible for the trial as the local authority has decided to provide alternative support in these cases. All other primary schools (94 schools in total) in the local authority will be eligible; all are expected to participate in the trial unless the school declines.

q13.value: 94 schools are involved in the study; comprising approximately 30,000 pupils

q14.value: The maximum sample size was determined by the number of primary schools within the local authority.

question.value:
Information on both primary and secondary outcomes will be obtained from administrative data that is already routinely collected by the local authority. 
 
The primary outcome will be based on new contacts made which result in no further action (at the point of contact) between October 2019 and February 2020. 
Secondary outcomes will be: 
New initial contacts with the social care system
New referrals to children’s social care
New referrals leading to a Child in Need assessment (section 17 starts)
New referrals leading to a child protection enquiry (section 47 starts)
New referrals leading to a child becoming a Looked After Child
New submissions of Early Help Plans

Information on school characteristics (for example, number of pupils by year group) will be used to construct a dataset effectively at “pupil” level.  Data on outcomes obtained at school level will then be assigned to the dataset. For example, if there are 100 pupils in a school, and there are 5 contacts to children’s social care services which lead to no further action, the dataset for that school will contain 100 rows, and the outcome indicator (in this example the number of contacts which lead to NFA) would be set to 1 for 5 of the rows and 0 for the remaining 95 rows.  

The analysis will be carried out using linear regression, with standard errors clustered by school.  The regression models used for the primary analysis will include controls for prior social care outcomes (here no further action at contact), based on the previous school year (at school level). The models will also include a dummy variable capturing treatment allocation and strata indicators. The estimated impact will be based on the difference between the intervention and control groups, regardless of contamination of the control schools or drop out by intervention schools. This is in order to estimate the “intention to treat” (ITT) effect.  



The analysis will be repeated for each of the secondary outcome measures specified above, using the same approach and model specification as described above for the primary outcome.

Please also see the trial protocol for details.

q20.value: As noted above, information on school characteristics (for example, number of pupils by year group) will be used to construct a dataset effectively at “pupil” level.  Data on outcomes obtained at school level will then be assigned to the dataset.

q21.value:
Effect sizes will be reported, expressed as a proportion of the standard deviation in the control group (Glass’s Delta), as per the WWCSC Evaluation Guidance. 

As there is one primary outcome measure the analyses will not be subject to multiple comparison adjustments.

attributes.title: Psychosocial disparities as mediators of increased risky sexual behaviour in sexual minorities: A twin approach
attributes.description:
Non-heterosexual individuals (i.e. those who identify as lesbian, gay or bisexual) report higher rates of mental health problems such as depression, suicidality, anxiety and substance use problems as well as social problems such as childhood adversity and intimate partner violence. These psychosocial difficulties have in turn been shown to be associated with increased risky sexual behaviour and risk for HIV infection in the general population and among non-heterosexual men. 
There is evidence that shared genetic and environmental factors respectively influence the association between mental health problems and sexual orientation, and risky sexual behaviour. The aetiology of the relationship between sexual orientation and disparities in psychosocial risk and risky sexual behaviour is not yet well understood. 
We recently demonstrated that increased mental health problems partly explained increased risky sexual behaviour among non-heterosexual individuals and that this mediation relationship was not confounded by shared aetiological influences. However, measures of social disparity were not included and the assessment of risky sexual behaviour was mostly based on the number of sexual partners. It will be informative to test this genetic model in a different sample incorporating better psychosocial variables and a broader index of risky sexual behaviour.

summary.value: This registration contains a description of background, the research questions and hypotheses, the data to be used, the list of variables to be used and the questionnaires used to assess them and the analysis plan.

attributes.title: Validating the Sense of Self Scale - VR

q1.value: Validation of the Sense of Self scale in a Virtual Reality task

q3.value:
We will validate our new measure, the Sense of Self scale in a virtual reality paradigm. Participants will experience a virtual reality rollercoaster ride and also watch a video of the same rollercoaster ride (repeated measures in counterbalanced order). 
After each condition we will administer an existing measure of presence (the ITC-SOPI Scale) and our new Sense of Self scale.

The Self Scale has 9 factors:
o	F1 Agency for actions and events [agency]
o	F2 Agency for thoughts [agency]
o	F3 Expected outcomes [agency]
o	F4 Body ownership [ownership]
o	F5 Thought ownership [ownership]
o	F6 Thought fidelity [ownership]
o	F7 Interactional fidelity [presence]
o	F8 Environmental fidelity [presence]

The ITC-SOPI has 4 factors:
-	Sense of physical space
-	Engagement
-	Ecological validity
-	Negative effects

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Participants will score higher on self scale factors related to presence (F7 – Interactional Fidelity and F8 – Environmental Fidelity) in the VR condition compared to the movie condition [Predictive criterion validity].

Hypothesis 2: Self Scale factors related to presence will be associated with ITC-SOPI factors [Convergent validity].
- F7 – Interactional Fidelity will be positively associated with all four ITC-SOPI factors.
- F8 – Environmental Fidelity will be positively associated with all four ITC-SOPI factors.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a within-subjects design with two levels (VR and movie conditions).

q9.value: Condition order will be randomised across participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Data collection is complete and is stored digitally. No one has accessed or viewed the data in any way.

question.value: Participants were recruited through the Macquarie University Psychology Students experiment pool. Participants will receive 45 mins participation credit.

q13.value: We aimed to recruit 52 participants in this study.

q14.value:
This sample size provides us with appropriate statistical power (power=0.80, alpha=0.05) to detect small to medium effect sizes (up to d=0.40) in paired t-test comparisons (two-sided; hypotheses 1).

This same size provides appropriate statistical power (power=0.80, alpha=0.05) to detect small to medium effect sizes (up to r=0.37) in our planned correlational analyses for hypothesis 2.

q15.value: We aimed to collect data from 52 participants. If we had not managed to recruit our quota of 52 participants by the conclusion of semester 2 2019 (December), then we planned to set a revised target of 34 participants. This revised number of participants would allow us to identify an effect of d=.5 (medium effect size) with 80% power and an alpha level of .05.

question.value: We will manipulate the type of media exposure between conditions. In the VR condition participants will experience an interactive virtual rollercoaster. In the movie condition participants will observe a non-interactive movie of a rollercoaster.

Following each condition we will administer the Sense of Self Scale and the ITC-SOPI Scale.
The self scale has 8 factor scores.
The ITC-SOPI has 4 factor scores.

First, we will investigate changes in self scale factor scores between conditions. 
Our test of hypothesis 1 will be whether there is a difference in F7 – Interactional Fidelity and F8 – Environmental Fidelity scores between conditions using a paired t-test.
As an exploratory analysis will also test for differences between conditions for all factors of the self scale (i.e. 6 additional tests).

Second, to test hypothesis 2, we will investigate whether the difference between conditions for each of F7 – Interactional Fidelity and F8 – Environmental Fidelity correlates with the difference between conditions for the four ITC-SOPI subscales. 
As an exploratory analysis we will also investigate bivariate correlations for the condition difference scores for the other self scale factor scores, proprioceptive drift and Embodiment factor scores. I.e., we will explore whether the differences between synchronous and asynchronous conditions for all measures are associated with one another.

q21.value: We will use an alpha level of p <.05 as the criteria for significance in all planned analyses.

q22.value:
We will exclude participants who make obviously disingenuous responses on the Sense of Self and ITC-SOPI scales. Specifically we will exclude participants who provide the same rating for > 80% items.

We will also exclude extreme outliers for factor totals, defined as any score that is more than three standard deviations from the group mean. We will exclude specific outlier scores but retain other data.

q23.value: The design of our survey measures should prevent any missing data. If there is missing data for any reason, records will be exluded on a case-wise basis. That is, specific factor totals will be excluded but data from that participant will be included in other analyses.

attributes.title: Changes in Personality Traits and Life Goals in the Transition to Young Adulthood and their association with Occupational Creativity
attributes.description: The overarching project has two primary goals: (1) to examine how personality traits (including facet level measures) and goals develop and change during adolescence and young adulthood and (2) to examine whether changes in personality traits and goals (over and above initial levels of personality and goals) predict occupational creativity

summary.value:
Exploratory and Confirmatory Factor Analysis of 
Life Goals Measure in two Longitudinal Samples

Summary: This registration document contains the analysis plan for a factorial analysis of a Life Goal measure. After this analysis, we plan to use this measure in a project that will assess changes in personality traits and facets and life goals and their relationships with occupational creativity. This project will use data from two existing datasets. The overarching project has two primary goals: (1) to examine how personality traits (including facet level measures) and goals develop and change during adolescence and young adulthood and (2) to examine whether changes in personality traits and goals (over and above initial levels of personality and goals) predict occupational creativity. We will follow 2 steps in preregistering this project: At step 1 (current document) we register our analysis plan for the exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis for the life goals measure employed in the study. After evaluating the factorial structure of the goals measure, and in light of the factorial analyses results, we will register hypotheses and research questions at step 2. Both registration documents follow the preregistration template, “Preregistration of secondary data analysis: A template and tutorial” (den Akker et al., 2019). 

Part 1: Study information
Q1: Provide the working title of your study.
 
A1: Changes in Personality Traits and Life Goals in the Transition to Young Adulthood and their association with Occupational Creativity

Q2: Name the authors of this preregistration. 

A2: 
Andreea Sutu 
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3958-3154
Rodica Damian
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0046-0627
Kevin Hoff 
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3265-2209
Sif Einarsdóttir
 ORCID https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8039-5203
James Rounds

Q3: List each research question included in this study.
A3: At step 1 of this preregistration, our research question is: What is the factor structure of the Life Goals measure employed in this study?

Q4: For each of the research questions listed in the previous section, provide one or more specific and testable hypotheses, and make it clear whether the hypotheses are directional (e.g., A > B) or non-directional (e.g., A ≠ B). If directional, state the direction.
 
A4: We expect that the measure will show a factorial make-up similar to the one emerging in previous studies that have employed a longer version of this measure (Roberts & Robins,2000) or different samples (Stoll et al., under review). 

Part 2: Data description 
Q5: Name and briefly describe the dataset(s), and if applicable, the subset(s) of the data you plan to use.
 

A5:	The study will use two existing longitudinal datasets collected over a 12-year span.
Sample 1 (N1 = 485) was younger and more homogenous in age at time one (average age = 15.3 years, SD = 0.5) compared to Sample 2 (average age = 17.9, SD = 3.5). Sample 1 was assessed over five waves (time 1, and two-, six-, eight- and eleven-years later), while Sample 2 (N2 = 1,368) was assessed over three waves (time 1 and six- and twelve-years later).  Both samples were representative of the Icelandic student population. Participation was voluntary and not compensated. 

Q6: Specify whether this data is open or publicly available.
 
A6: The data are not publicly available. 

Q7: How can the data be accessed? Provide a persistent identifier or link if the data are available online, or give a description of how you obtained the dataset.
 
A7: The data cannot be publicly accessed.

Q8: Specify the date of download and/or access.
 

A8: Andreea Sutu and Rodica Damian have not yet accessed the data at the time of the current preregistration. 

Kevin Hoff has accessed the data for previous papers using the personality and vocational interest measures. Kevin first accessed the dataset in Fall 2016, but has not analyzed the data for the proposed study (i.e., the life goals items and personality facets).
Sif Einarsdóttir and James Rounds collected the data beginning in 2006. They have not analyzed the life goals and personality facets data.

Q9: If the data collection procedure is well documented, provide a link to that information. If the data collection procedure is not well documented, describe, to the best of your ability, how data were collected.
 
A9: The data for both samples was first collected in 2006 across eighty randomly chosen schools (forty for each sample). A website link with access to the measures was sent through e-mail to participants who accepted to take part in the study. E-mails were sent to request participation, followed by phone calls to non-responders for the following waves for each sample.  The dataset and the collection procedure is described in detail here: Hoff, Song, Einarsdóttir, Briley, & Rounds, 2018, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, DOI: 10.1037/pspp0000228.

Q10: Some studies offer codebooks to describe their data. If such a codebook is publicly available, link to it here or upload the document. If not, provide other available documentation. Also provide guidance on what parts of the codebook or other documentation are most relevant. 
A10: A codebook is available on Step 2 of the preregistration process which will include all measures used in the project. 

Part 3: Variables 
Q11: If you are going to use any manipulated variables, identify them here. Describe the variables and the levels or treatment arms of each variable (note that this is not applicable for observational studies and meta-analyses). If you are collapsing groups across variables this should be explicitly stated, including the relevant formula.
 
A11: Not applicable

Q12: If you are going to use any measured variables, identify them here. Describe both outcome measures as well as predictors and covariates and label them accordingly. If you are using a scale (a set of items that have an underlying latent construct) or an index (a set of items that directly indicate a value or quantity), state the construct the scale/index represents, which items the scale/index will consist of, how these items will be aggregated, and whether this aggregation is based on a recommendation from the study codebook or validation research. If you are using any categorical variables, state how you will code them in the statistical analyses. 

A12: The Major Life Goals measure employed is the same across both samples. The study measure was based on the major life goals proposed by Roberts and Robins (2000) which contained 35 items across seven broad domains: Economic, Aesthetic, Social, Relationship, Political, Hedonistic, and Religious life goals. However, the current study measure used only 26 of the life goals listed in the original measure, along with two additional items that aimed to assess goals related to education (27 items in total). Exploration and validation of the current study life goals measure is warranted, given that we employ a different number of items and a different wording of items compared to the original measure. 
Participants rated the importance of 27 life goals on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (not important to me) to 5 (very important to me). The complete list of items is shown below.
1.	Having an exciting lifestyle
2.	Helping others in need
3.	Devoting attention to my spiritual life
4.	Having a high standard of living and wealth
5.	Owning my own business
6.	Having harmonious relationship with my parents and siblings
7.	Having fun
8.	Having children
9.	Having good grades in school
10.	Being influential in public affairs
11.	Becoming accomplished in one of the performing arts
12.	Having new and different experiences
13.	Write good fiction and prose
14.	Having a career
15.	Supporting artistic activities and fine arts
16.	Obtaining a high school degree
17.	Taking part in volunteer community and public service
18.	Participating in religious activity
19.	Prepare myself for graduate school
20.	Having a satisfying marriage/relationship
21.	Becoming a community leader
22.	Having a high-status career
23.	Be an accomplished musician
24.	Becoming an authority on a special subject in my field
25.	Becoming a business executive
26.	Produce good artistic work
27.	Working to promote the welfare of others

Q13: Which units of analysis (respondents, cases, etc.) will be included or excluded in your study? Taking these inclusion/exclusion criteria into account, indicate the (expected) sample size of the data you’ll be using for your statistical analyses (to the best of your knowledge). In the next few questions, you will be asked to refine this sample size estimation based on your judgments about missing data and outliers. 
A13. The Table below summarizes the sample sizes at each wave.

Part 4: Knowledge of data 

Q17: List the publications, conference presentations (papers, posters), and working papers (in prep, unpublished, preprints) you have worked on that are based on the data set. Describe which variables you have previously analyzed and which information you used in these analyses. Limit yourself to variables that are relevant to the current study. If the dataset is longitudinal, include information about what wave of data was previously analyzed. 
Importantly, some of your team members may have used this dataset and others may not have. It is therefore important to specify the relevant work from every co-author separately. If possible, mention other researchers’ work with this dataset that is relevant to the current preregistration.
 

A17: Below we provide a list of all existing publications, presentations, and working papers what have used the datasets. 
Up to date, there is one paper that has employed the Life Goals measure from Sample 2, wave 1: 

Stoll, G., Einarsdottir, S., Song, Q.C., Ondish, P., Sun J., Rounds, J. (under review). The Roles of Personality Traits and Vocational Interests in Explaining What People Want out of Life.  Journal blinded for review.

The following studies have employed one or both of the samples that will be used in our study. None of these has employed the Life Goals measure. 
Hanna, L. Einarsdóttir, S., Briley, D. A., Hoff, K. A. Rounds, J. (working paper). Have You Followed Your Interests? A Longitudinal Examination of Changes in Interest Fit in Educational and Work Contexts. 
Hoff, K. A., Song, Q. C., Einarsdóttir, S., Briley, D. A., Rounds, J. (in press). Developmental structure of personality and interests: A 4-wave, 8-year longitudinal study. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. DOI: 10.1037/pspp0000228

Q18: What prior knowledge do you have at the time of preregistration about trends in the data set you will be working with? For example, are you aware of summary statistics or the statistical distribution of variables, or do you know about correlations between variables? Also provide any relevant knowledge of different subsets of the data (e.g., a different wave than you will be using). Finally, provide information about your prior knowledge for every author separately.
 
A18: The authors have no previous knowledge about trend in the Life Goals measure in the present samples. Overall we expect to find similar results to Roberts & Robins (2000) and Stoll et al (under review), but the longitudinal items are slightly different which is why we are redoing it. 
	
Part 5: Analyses 
To test the factorial structure of the Life Goals measure, we will perform an Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA) on the large sample (Sample 2). We will then use the resulting factorial structure to apply a Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA) on the smaller sample (Sample 1).
Step 1: Exploratory Factor Analysis
The 27 item pool in Sample 2 will be analyzed using a principal factor analysis (henceforth PFA) with oblique rotation. We make no a priori assumptions regarding the relationships among factors. The extraction of factors will be based on the bass-ackwards method developed by Goldberg (2006). The bass-ackwards method is a top-down approach which starts with extracting one factor, and then extracting an increasing number factors (two factors, then three, then four, and so on) until the factor structure is not interpretable anymore.
This technique is based on levels of abstraction The first factor to be extracted is the largest one possible, and the next one is therefore smaller than the previous. “Each subsequent principal factor extracted is completely orthogonal to all of those extracted before it. In other words, the first principal factor provides a measure of whatever is most in common to the variables that have been included in the analysis, and each subsequent factor is as large as possible after the influence of all preceding factors has been partialed out” (Goldberg, 2006, p. 2). In line with the bass-ackwards technique, we plan to extract and rotate the factors until the factors can no longer be meaningfully interpreted (Jackson, Wood, Bogg, Walton, Harms, & Roberts, 2010). 
Factor Extraction: We will employ PFA with oblique rotation using full information maximum likelihood information. In line with the bass-ackwards technique (Goldberg, 2006), we will run a series of PFA extractions. First, we will run a one-factor PFA. Then, we will run a two-factor PFA and so on, and so forth, until the factors cannot be interpretable anymore. 

Step 2: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
In Step 2, the factor structure emerged in Step 1 will be tested in a different sample (Sample 1) with a Confirmatory Factor Analysis (henceforth CFA). We will specify the factor structure for the CFA based on the PFA results from Step 1. In the CFA model, each indicator (item) will be allowed to correlate with one factor only. Factors will be allowed to correlate among each other, and errors will be allowed to correlate.
The fit of the model will be assessed via the chi-square statistic, which tests the overall fit and the discrepancy between the sample and fitted covariance matrices. A non-significant test indicates good model fit.  
For all analyses, we will assess model fit via chi-square and degrees of freedom, CFI values (where values greater than .95 indicate a close fit, values between .90-.95 indicate an acceptable fit, and values between .85-.90 indicate a mediocre fit), and the root-mean-square error of approximation (RMSEA) (where values smaller than .05 indicate a close fit, values between .05-.08 indicate an acceptable fit, and values between .08-.10 indicate a mediocre fit) (Little, 2013).

registration_responses.summary:
Exploratory and Confirmatory Factor Analysis of 
Life Goals Measure in two Longitudinal Samples

Summary: This registration document contains the analysis plan for a factorial analysis of a Life Goal measure. After this analysis, we plan to use this measure in a project that will assess changes in personality traits and facets and life goals and their relationships with occupational creativity. This project will use data from two existing datasets. The overarching project has two primary goals: (1) to examine how personality traits (including facet level measures) and goals develop and change during adolescence and young adulthood and (2) to examine whether changes in personality traits and goals (over and above initial levels of personality and goals) predict occupational creativity. We will follow 2 steps in preregistering this project: At step 1 (current document) we register our analysis plan for the exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis for the life goals measure employed in the study. After evaluating the factorial structure of the goals measure, and in light of the factorial analyses results, we will register hypotheses and research questions at step 2. Both registration documents follow the preregistration template, “Preregistration of secondary data analysis: A template and tutorial” (den Akker et al., 2019). 

Part 1: Study information
Q1: Provide the working title of your study.
 
A1: Changes in Personality Traits and Life Goals in the Transition to Young Adulthood and their association with Occupational Creativity

Q2: Name the authors of this preregistration. 

A2: 
Andreea Sutu 
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3958-3154
Rodica Damian
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0046-0627
Kevin Hoff 
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3265-2209
Sif Einarsdóttir
 ORCID https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8039-5203
James Rounds

Q3: List each research question included in this study.
A3: At step 1 of this preregistration, our research question is: What is the factor structure of the Life Goals measure employed in this study?

Q4: For each of the research questions listed in the previous section, provide one or more specific and testable hypotheses, and make it clear whether the hypotheses are directional (e.g., A > B) or non-directional (e.g., A ≠ B). If directional, state the direction.
 
A4: We expect that the measure will show a factorial make-up similar to the one emerging in previous studies that have employed a longer version of this measure (Roberts & Robins,2000) or different samples (Stoll et al., under review). 

Part 2: Data description 
Q5: Name and briefly describe the dataset(s), and if applicable, the subset(s) of the data you plan to use.
 

A5:	The study will use two existing longitudinal datasets collected over a 12-year span.
Sample 1 (N1 = 485) was younger and more homogenous in age at time one (average age = 15.3 years, SD = 0.5) compared to Sample 2 (average age = 17.9, SD = 3.5). Sample 1 was assessed over five waves (time 1, and two-, six-, eight- and eleven-years later), while Sample 2 (N2 = 1,368) was assessed over three waves (time 1 and six- and twelve-years later).  Both samples were representative of the Icelandic student population. Participation was voluntary and not compensated. 

Q6: Specify whether this data is open or publicly available.
 
A6: The data are not publicly available. 

Q7: How can the data be accessed? Provide a persistent identifier or link if the data are available online, or give a description of how you obtained the dataset.
 
A7: The data cannot be publicly accessed.

Q8: Specify the date of download and/or access.
 

A8: Andreea Sutu and Rodica Damian have not yet accessed the data at the time of the current preregistration. 

Kevin Hoff has accessed the data for previous papers using the personality and vocational interest measures. Kevin first accessed the dataset in Fall 2016, but has not analyzed the data for the proposed study (i.e., the life goals items and personality facets).
Sif Einarsdóttir and James Rounds collected the data beginning in 2006. They have not analyzed the life goals and personality facets data.

Q9: If the data collection procedure is well documented, provide a link to that information. If the data collection procedure is not well documented, describe, to the best of your ability, how data were collected.
 
A9: The data for both samples was first collected in 2006 across eighty randomly chosen schools (forty for each sample). A website link with access to the measures was sent through e-mail to participants who accepted to take part in the study. E-mails were sent to request participation, followed by phone calls to non-responders for the following waves for each sample.  The dataset and the collection procedure is described in detail here: Hoff, Song, Einarsdóttir, Briley, & Rounds, 2018, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, DOI: 10.1037/pspp0000228.

Q10: Some studies offer codebooks to describe their data. If such a codebook is publicly available, link to it here or upload the document. If not, provide other available documentation. Also provide guidance on what parts of the codebook or other documentation are most relevant. 
A10: A codebook is available on Step 2 of the preregistration process which will include all measures used in the project. 

Part 3: Variables 
Q11: If you are going to use any manipulated variables, identify them here. Describe the variables and the levels or treatment arms of each variable (note that this is not applicable for observational studies and meta-analyses). If you are collapsing groups across variables this should be explicitly stated, including the relevant formula.
 
A11: Not applicable

A12: The Major Life Goals measure employed is the same across both samples. The study measure was based on the major life goals proposed by Roberts and Robins (2000) which contained 35 items across seven broad domains: Economic, Aesthetic, Social, Relationship, Political, Hedonistic, and Religious life goals. However, the current study measure used only 26 of the life goals listed in the original measure, along with two additional items that aimed to assess goals related to education (27 items in total). Exploration and validation of the current study life goals measure is warranted, given that we employ a different number of items and a different wording of items compared to the original measure.

attributes.title: How physical appearance impacts our moral attitudes concerning cognitive enhancement

q1.value: Cognitive enhancement in the facially different: Leveling the playing field or playing a dangerous game?

q2.value: Charlie Siegel, Stacey Humphries, Clifford Workman, Anjan Chatterjee

q3.value:
Public attitudes towards cognitive enhancement (CE) -- e.g., using stimulants like Adderall and Ritalin to improve mental functioning -- are mixed and vary by context. Research on contextual factors has emphasized the environment of use, reasons for use (e.g. enhancement vs. reparation), personal history with CE, permissibility / legality, social norms, and knowledge about safety and efficacy. Such factors prompt ethical concerns at the societal level regarding fairness of CE, coercion to enhance, and authenticity following CE use (Chatterjee, 2006; Conrad, Humphries, & Chatterjee, 2019; McCabe et al., 2005; Sattler et al., 2013). Research on folk moral attitudes towards CE has further revealed a disjunction between moral beliefs (i.e. judgments of moral acceptability) and moral actions (i.e. reported willingness to use CE) relating to CE use (Medaglia et al., 2019; Sattler et al., 2013).

Our group recently found that the presence or absence of irrelevant social information -- namely, visible facial differences (e.g., scars, warts) -- modulated perceptions of moral character (Jamrozik et al., 2019). By contrast, typically attractive people receive more social benefits, such as successes in job applications and promotions and reductions in criminal sentences. This phenomenon is called the "beauty is good" stereotype. In view of our group’s findings, we have proposed an analogous "anomalous is bad" stereotype, whereby people with facial anomalies are viewed as morally deficient and treated worse than others. Here, “anomaly” refers to “a scar, blemish or deformity which severely [affects the] ability to lead a normal life” (Patridge & D, 2008).

This study will examine whether one aspect of physical appearance -- namely, the presence or absence of a visible facial anomaly -- influences the morality of CE use. Specifically, the following questions will be addressed: (1) Do people judge the use of CE differently depending on the presence or absence of facial anomalies? (2) Do we treat CE use differently depending on the presence of facial anomalies?

q4.value:
● Hypothesis 1: Facial anomalies influence moral judgments about cognitive enhancement.
○ Prediction 1A: Anomalous faces will elicit more moral opposition to cognitive enhancement than typical faces. Increased moral opposition would be consistent with the view that anomalous faces signal an underlying moral deficiency that might be exacerbated with CE use.
○ Prediction 1B: Anomalous faces will elicit less moral opposition to cognitive enhancement than typical faces. Since facial anomalies are reportedly indicative of impaired competence, less opposition may reflect a desire to “level the playing field” for people already at a disadvantage.

● Hypothesis 2: Facial anomalies influence the moral treatment of one’s social partners depending on whether they’ve used cognitive enhancement pills.
○ Prediction 2A: Participants will give more money to people with anomalous faces compared to non-anomalous faces. This may occur only after CE use, or irrespective of CE use. If observed, such behavior could be motivated by sympathy or even pity for the facially anomalous.
○ Prediction 2B: Participants will give less money to people with anomalous faces irrespective of CE use. This would be consistent with previous work showing anomalous faces are judged to be less competent.
○ Prediction 2C: Participants will give more money to people who choose to enhance, compared to people who choose to abstain. This would suggest CE enhances beliefs in competence.
○ Prediction 2D: Participants will give less money to people who choose to enhance, compared to people who choose to abstain. This would suggest CE reduces warmth (i.e. belief in trustworthiness).
○ Prediction 2E: Participants will give more money to people with anomalous faces if they used CE pills than if they didn’t. If observed, this would suggest that CE has a stronger effect on beliefs of warmth and competence towards people who are believed to lack these capacities.
○ Prediction 2F: Participants will give less money to people with anomalous faces if they used CE pills than if they didn’t. This would suggest that people believe CE is less effective in people with facial anomalies, and/or that people with anomalous faces are judged more harshly for using CE.

● Hypothesis 3: Facial anomalies and cognitive enhancement interact to shape beliefs about warmth  and competence.
○ Prediction 3A: People who enhance will be seen as more competent. Enhancement’s positive effects on competence will be larger for typical compared to anomalous faces.
○ Prediction 3B: People who enhance will be seen as less warm (i.e. trustworthy). Enhancement’s negative effects on warmth (i.e. trustworthiness) will be larger for anomalous compared to typical faces.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two face conditions (Anomalous | Non-Anomalous) as part of a between-subjects design. Participants will view a photo of a face alongside a vignette ostensibly about the person in the photograph (“M. Miller”), who reportedly considered using CE pills to deal with a stressful deadline at work. Participants will be informed that M. Miller told our team about this experience as part of our lab’s research on CE, and that they also completed a cognitive test to measure mental speed and memory. Participants in both conditions will make moral judgments about CE in reference to the vignette. The first question will ask whether it would be fair for M. Miller to use CE. The second will ask whether M. Miller ought to use CE. The third will ask whether M. Miller’s work would be authentic (i.e., reflecting their own actual skills) if they used CE. Next, participants will be randomly assigned to one of two enhancement outcome conditions, where they will be told whether or not M. Miller decided to enhance (Enhanced | Abstained). This will result in four conditions: anomalous-enhanced, anomalous-abstained, non-anomalous-enhanced, non-anomalous-abstained. Participants in each of the four new conditions will complete a behavioral Trust Game, ostensibly with M. Miller, to examine how facial anomalies and CE interact to influence prosocial behavior.

This study will use an adapted version of the classic Trust Game (Krueger, Grafman, & McCabe, 2008). Participants will be told they will decide how much of their study compensation (participants are told they will receive $2 that can be split in increments of $0.20), if any, to give M. Miller. They will be reminded that M. Miller previously completed a test of memory and mental speed. If M. Miller passed the test, participants will be told any money they sent is tripled. If M. Miller failed the test, however, any money they were given will instead be returned to the researchers. Finally, the participants will be informed that, if the money is tripled, M. Miller will decide how much, if any, to return to the participant. After deciding whether and how much money to give to M. Miller, participants will answer follow-up questions about factors that may have contributed to their decision. Specifically, they will be asked how confident they were that M. Miller had passed the test (competence), and how important this was to their decision to give money. Participants will also indicate how confident they were that M. Miller would split the money with them fairly (warmth / trustworthiness), and how important this was to their decision.

Finally, participants will provide basic demographic information and will describe any prior experiences with cognitive enhancement and physical disability. Participants will also complete a short battery of psychological questionnaires about empathy, sensitivity to disgust, social dominance orientation, and just world beliefs. At the end of the survey, participants will be debriefed about the true nature of the study and the use of deception will be explained. Since participants will be led to believe they could receive additional money, all participants will receive $6 for taking part - triple as much as they believed they would receive when signing up.

question.value: Healthy adult volunteers aged 18 and older from the United States will be recruited through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (M-Turk) service to complete an online survey administered via Qualtrics. This study has been reviewed and has received approval from the Institutional Review Board at the University of Pennsylvania. Participants will be compensated for their time ($6).The survey should take approximately 15 minutes to complete.

q13.value: A sample size of N = 1,000 participants will be enrolled (N = 500 anomalous [250 enhanced, 250 abstained]; N = 500 non-anomalous [250 enhanced, 250 abstained]).

q14.value: We used an effect size of d = 0.2, typically indicative of a small effect in psychological research, to inform a power analysis (α = 0.05; 1 – β = 0.8). This power analysis suggested a total sample size of N = 788 participants (394 per group) is required to detect the effects of interest in this study. We will recruit a sample of N = 1,000 participants in total to ensure low quality data can be excluded without sacrificing statistical power. Another study conducted by our group, which examined the influence of two different social contexts on acceptability judgments of CE usage (Dinh, Humphries, & Chatterjee, under review), reported a similar effect size. Furthermore, meta-analyses of cooperative behavioral economic games including the Trust Game report effects of intergroup biases on economic gameplay that are similar in magnitude. In view of these findings, this study should be adequately powered to detect all effects of interest.

question.value: Face type (Anomalous | Non-Anomalous) and whether or not the character described in the hypothetical scenario ultimately used CE pills (Enhanced | Abstained).

Participants will make several moral judgments in response to a hypothetical scenario, wherein employee “M. Miller” considers using CE pills to meet a tight deadline. First, participants will be asked: “Given the tight project deadline, would it be fair for M. Miller to take this cognitive enhancement pill for work?” Second, participants will be asked: “Given the tight project deadline, should M. Miller take this cognitive enhancement pill?” Third, participants will be asked: “If M. Miller were to take the cognitive enhancement pill, do you think that the project work would reflect their own actual skills?” Participants will respond using 7-point Likert scales (1 = Absolutely not, 7 = Absolutely yes).

Next, aspects of moral behavior relating to CE use will be assessed. Participants will complete an adaptation of the classic Trust Game. In this game, participants will decide how much money to send M. Miller ($2 maximum, $0.20 increments). After deciding whether and how much money to give, participants will judge M. Miller’s warmth (operationalized as trustworthiness) and competence and indicate how important these beliefs were to their decision to give money. Warmth beliefs will be measured with the following questions: 1A. “How confident were you that M. Miller would share the money fairly with you?” 1B. “How much was your decision to send money to M. Miller based on whether you thought they would share the money fairly with you?” Competence beliefs will be assessed with the following questions: 2A. “How confident were you that M. Miller would pass the memory test?” 2B. “How much was your decision to send money to M. Miller based on whether you thought they passed the memory task?” Responses to all four questions were recorded with identical Likert scales (1 = Not at all, 7 = Entirely).

Participants will also complete a battery of self-report measures to assess psychological dispositions relating to justice, egalitarianism, and moral / aesthetic emotions: The Procedural and Distributive Just World Beliefs Scale (PaDJWBS) will measure beliefs regarding the extent to which the world is just – both in terms of allocations (i.e., distributive justice) and rules / processes (i.e., procedural justice; Lucas, Zhdanova, & Alexander, 2011). The Social Dominance Orientation (SDO) scale will measure beliefs about group-based dominance and inequality (Pratto et al., 1994). The Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI) will measure aspects of empathy, including its cognitive (perspective-taking) and emotional (empathic concern) components (Davis, 1983). The Three-Domain Disgust (3DD) scale will measure sensitivity to experiencing pathogen-, sexual-, and moral-related disgust (Tybur, Lieberman, & Griskevicius, 2009). Demographic information, such as age and education, will also be collected.

Independent samples t-tests will identify between-subject differences in moral judgments (i.e., fairness, responsibility, and authenticity) depending on face condition (Anomalous | Non-Anomalous). Analysis of variance (ANOVAs) will identify between-subject differences in moral behavior, as assessed with the modified Trust Game. Specifically, ANOVAs will test for main effects of face type and of enhancement outcome (Enhanced | Abstained), as well as interactions between them, on amount given, and ratings of warmth and competence (and their importance).

q20.value: For the measures of moral judgment, Likert scores (1 = Absolutely not, 7 = Absolutely yes) will be rescaled to range from -3 to +3, with positive numbers indicating more approval of CE and vice versa.

q21.value: Significance will be determined with an alpha = 0.05, with Benjamini-Hochberg correction to control the false discovery rate.

q22.value: We will use M-Turk’s sample restriction features to ensure participants are: based in the US, have a high school education or better, and have successfully completed several hundred MTurk jobs with high approval ratings prior to participating in this study. We will use an attention check following the presentation of the hypothetical scenario to ensure participants are engaged with the survey. The attention check will ask a question based on information reported in the scenario, which participants can only answer correctly if they read the scenario carefully. Participants will be informed that, if they respond to the attention check incorrectly, they will be excluded from the study and will not receive full payment.

q23.value: We have designed the survey such that all responses are required and participants cannot advance without responding to each question. The survey is split into three parts: 1. Moral judgments of CE in response to a hypothetical scenario, 2. Trust Game, and 3. demographic and self-report measures. In the event a participant does not fully complete all three sections, we will include them in analyses of outcome measures where their data are complete but exclude them from analyses where their data are incomplete. For example, if a participant completes part 1 but not parts 2 or 3, we will include them in the analysis of part 1 data only. This person would also be excluded from analyses where part 3 measures are correlated with part 1 measures. We will report the number of instances where data are incomplete in publications describing the results of the study.

q24.value: Exploratory analyses will test whether individual differences in psychological dispositions (described in the Measured Variables section) predict our primary outcome measures (1. Fairness, responsibility, and authenticity judgments in response to the hypothetical scenario, 2. Amount donated and competence / trustworthiness ratings in the Trust Game). The results may help us identify potential drivers of such judgments and behaviors towards CE and anomalous faces, on which we hope to form a confirmatory hypothesis to be tested in a future study. We will use correlations to test each relationship individually, as well as multiple regression to assess the impact of variables after controlling for others. If several factors emerge as potentially important, we will conduct analyses of “relative importance” to quantify the contribution of each regressor to the model.

registration_responses.q1: Cognitive enhancement in the facially different: Leveling the playing field or playing a dangerous game?
registration_responses.q2: Charlie Siegel, Stacey Humphries, Clifford Workman, Anjan Chatterjee
registration_responses.q3:
Public attitudes towards cognitive enhancement (CE) -- e.g., using stimulants like Adderall and Ritalin to improve mental functioning -- are mixed and vary by context. Research on contextual factors has emphasized the environment of use, reasons for use (e.g. enhancement vs. reparation), personal history with CE, permissibility / legality, social norms, and knowledge about safety and efficacy. Such factors prompt ethical concerns at the societal level regarding fairness of CE, coercion to enhance, and authenticity following CE use (Chatterjee, 2006; Conrad, Humphries, & Chatterjee, 2019; McCabe et al., 2005; Sattler et al., 2013). Research on folk moral attitudes towards CE has further revealed a disjunction between moral beliefs (i.e. judgments of moral acceptability) and moral actions (i.e. reported willingness to use CE) relating to CE use (Medaglia et al., 2019; Sattler et al., 2013).

Our group recently found that the presence or absence of irrelevant social information -- namely, visible facial differences (e.g., scars, warts) -- modulated perceptions of moral character (Jamrozik et al., 2019). By contrast, typically attractive people receive more social benefits, such as successes in job applications and promotions and reductions in criminal sentences. This phenomenon is called the "beauty is good" stereotype. In view of our group’s findings, we have proposed an analogous "anomalous is bad" stereotype, whereby people with facial anomalies are viewed as morally deficient and treated worse than others. Here, “anomaly” refers to “a scar, blemish or deformity which severely [affects the] ability to lead a normal life” (Patridge & D, 2008).

This study will examine whether one aspect of physical appearance -- namely, the presence or absence of a visible facial anomaly -- influences the morality of CE use. Specifically, the following questions will be addressed: (1) Do people judge the use of CE differently depending on the presence or absence of facial anomalies? (2) Do we treat CE use differently depending on the presence of facial anomalies?
registration_responses.q4:
● Hypothesis 1: Facial anomalies influence moral judgments about cognitive enhancement.
○ Prediction 1A: Anomalous faces will elicit more moral opposition to cognitive enhancement than typical faces. Increased moral opposition would be consistent with the view that anomalous faces signal an underlying moral deficiency that might be exacerbated with CE use.
○ Prediction 1B: Anomalous faces will elicit less moral opposition to cognitive enhancement than typical faces. Since facial anomalies are reportedly indicative of impaired competence, less opposition may reflect a desire to “level the playing field” for people already at a disadvantage.

● Hypothesis 2: Facial anomalies influence the moral treatment of one’s social partners depending on whether they’ve used cognitive enhancement pills.
○ Prediction 2A: Participants will give more money to people with anomalous faces compared to non-anomalous faces. This may occur only after CE use, or irrespective of CE use. If observed, such behavior could be motivated by sympathy or even pity for the facially anomalous.
○ Prediction 2B: Participants will give less money to people with anomalous faces irrespective of CE use. This would be consistent with previous work showing anomalous faces are judged to be less competent.
○ Prediction 2C: Participants will give more money to people who choose to enhance, compared to people who choose to abstain. This would suggest CE enhances beliefs in competence.
○ Prediction 2D: Participants will give less money to people who choose to enhance, compared to people who choose to abstain. This would suggest CE reduces warmth (i.e. belief in trustworthiness).
○ Prediction 2E: Participants will give more money to people with anomalous faces if they used CE pills than if they didn’t. If observed, this would suggest that CE has a stronger effect on beliefs of warmth and competence towards people who are believed to lack these capacities.
○ Prediction 2F: Participants will give less money to people with anomalous faces if they used CE pills than if they didn’t. This would suggest that people believe CE is less effective in people with facial anomalies, and/or that people with anomalous faces are judged more harshly for using CE.

● Hypothesis 3: Facial anomalies and cognitive enhancement interact to shape beliefs about warmth  and competence.
○ Prediction 3A: People who enhance will be seen as more competent. Enhancement’s positive effects on competence will be larger for typical compared to anomalous faces.
○ Prediction 3B: People who enhance will be seen as less warm (i.e. trustworthy). Enhancement’s negative effects on warmth (i.e. trustworthiness) will be larger for anomalous compared to typical faces.

attributes.title: Evaluation of Predictive Qualities of Drinking Motives in Relation to Alcohol-Related Problems: The Development of a Novel Psychometric Questionnaire to Measure Drinking Motivations
attributes.description: This project is attempting to provide an increased level of homogeneity amongst the drinking motives literature by administering a comprehensive list of unique motives taken from previously used scales and using the responses to re-evaluate the underlying factor structure of individuals' motivations to consume alcohol. This new factor structure will then be compared to the predictive ability of the Drinking Motives Questionnaire - Revised (DMQ-R; Cooper, 1994) at both an initial baseline session and after a six-month follow-up period.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Evaluation of Predictive Qualities of Drinking Motives in Relation to Alcohol-Related Problems: The Development of a Novel Psychometric Questionnaire to Measure Drinking Motivations

other.value:
Several individual difference variables will be assessed. These variables include social variables (e.g., social anxiety via the Social Interaction and Anxiety Scale [SIAS]; Mattick and Clark, 1998); personality variables (e.g., The Neuroticism-Extraversion-Openness Five Factor Inventory-Revised version 3 [NEO-60; Costa & McCrae, 1992], and the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 – Brief Form [PID-5-BF; Krueger, Derringer, Markon, Watson, & Skodol; 2013]; depression symptoms (e.g., the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 [PHQ-9; Kroenke, Spitzer, & Williams, 2001]; and general anxiety symptoms (e.g., the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 questionnaire [GAD-7; Spitzer, Kroenke, Williams, & Lowe, 2006]. 

Data for this study has been collected through a Qualtrics panel. Baseline data has been made available to researchers prior to when this preregistration was completed; 6 month follow-up data collection is ongoing.

sample.value: Given the large number of items we anticipated including in the factor analyses (N = 205), and given prior experience and relevant research as indicated by the literature, we decided that approximately 1000 participants were needed to measure drinking motives and perform hierarchical factor analyses to determine specific factors that each motive fits into, as well as accurately track changes in drinking behavior and alcohol-related problems over a six-month follow-up period.

analyses.value:
Primary analysis for this study will consist of Exploratory Hierarchical Factor Analysis utilizing the “Bassackwards” method (Goldberg, 2006) to find the appropriate factor structure for the new drinking motives questionnaire. This method is a top-down approach to exploratory factor analysis that first extracts one principle factor from a data set, and then two are extracted and rotated, then three, and so on until there is a factor that no variable has its highest factor (Goldberg, 2006). Horn’s Parallel Analysis will first be run to determine the maximum number of factors that should be considered. Factors will be extracted via principle axis factoring with a direct oblimin rotation, since all motives to consume alcohol are assumed to be correlated with each other. 

Multiple linear regression analyses will be used with both the newly developed drinking motives scale and the Drinking Motives Questionnaire-Revised (DMQ-R; Cooper, 1994) as the continuous predictor variables and pertinent alcohol-related outcomes (i.e., AUDIT scores, YAACQ-B scores, quantity and frequency of alcohol consumption) will serve as the continuous outcome variables. Covariates at baseline will include gender, age, ethnicity, and education level. Baseline drinking behavior and problems will be included as covariates in the 6-month follow-up analyses in order to test whether drinking motives at baseline predict changes in drinking behavior and problems over follow-up.

dependent.value:
The key dependent variables will be alcohol problems and alcohol-related behaviors. These will be measured through several different questionnaires.

Alcohol problems will be measured through the administration of the Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test (AUDIT; Saunders, Aasland, Babor, De la Fuente, & Grant, 1993), and the Brief Young Adult Alcohol Consequences Questionnaire (B-YAACQ; Kahler, Strong, & Read, 2005). The AUDIT is designed to assess problematic alcohol use and related behavior. The B-YAACQ assesses negative consequences associated with alcohol use. 

Alcohol-related behaviors will be assessed with the Drinking Refusal Self-Efficacy Questionnaire – Revised (DRSEQ-R; Oei, Hasking, & Young, 2005). The DRSEQ-R assesses a person’s belief in their ability to resist alcohol in social pressure situations, emotional relief situations, and opportunistic situations. Past year and past month alcohol use quantity and frequency, as well as frequency of binge drinking were measured using the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism’s (NIAAA) alcohol consumption question set (NIAAA, 2003). Age of first drink, age of first intoxication, past year maximum drink quantity during one occasion, and frequency of drinking that maximum amount were also assessed (NIAAA, 2003). Solitary drinking was also measured by asking participants to indicate the percentage of time (on a 0 – 100% scale) their drinking occurred while alone (i.e., “without anyone else around”) versus with others since they began drinking (Creswell et al., 2014; Creswell et al., 2015, Skrzynski et al., 2018).

conditions.value: This is a correlational study, so participants will not be assigned to conditions. Participants’ motivations to consume alcohol will be assessed via the administration of an experimenter-created psychometric scale consisting of 205 unique items. 197 Items for this scale were drawn from previously used scales cited by Kuntsche et al. in 2005. Eight additional items were adapted from the Brief Fear of Negative Evaluation Scale (Leary, 1983; Rodebaugh et. al., 2004). Participants were presented with the following instructions before completing the questionnaire: “Listed below are reasons people might be inclined to drink alcoholic beverages.  Using the five-point scale below, decide how frequently your own drinking is motivated by each of the reasons listed.” The wording of all items was modified from their original version to fit the root “You drink…”.  Relative frequency of drinking in response to each item was rated on a 5-Point Likert Scale (1 = Almost Never/Never, 2 = Some of the time, 3 = Half of the time, 4 = Most of the time, 5 = Almost Always/Always). To ensure that response biases and participant fatigue did not factor into responses, items were randomized in their presentation.

hypothesis.value:
The purpose of this study is to develop a new psychometric scale to assess young adult drinking motives. We will test the concurrent and predictive validity of the scale by examining its association to the Drinking Motives Questionnaire-Revised (DMQ-R; Cooper, 1994) at baseline and related behavioral outcomes (e.g., alcohol use and problems) at baseline and 6-month follow-up (controlling for baseline alcohol use and problems). 

While many different factors are associated with alcohol use, one compelling theory is that drinking motives (i.e., reasons individuals give for drinking alcohol) serve as a final mediator by which all other behavioral, psychological, and biological factors converge upon (Cooper, 1994; Cox & Klinger, 1988). Indeed, drinking motives have been shown to be robustly predictive of both alcohol consumption and alcohol-related problems. For example, several studies show that increased social (e.g., drinking to enjoy a social event) (Cooper, 1994; Feldman et al., 1999; Kairouz et al., 2002; Kassel, Jackson, & Unrod, 2000; Kuntsche et al., 2005; Weinberger & Bartholomew, 1996; Windle, 1996; Windle & Windle, 1996), enhancement (e.g., drinking to get drunk), and coping motives (e.g., drinking to cheer up when you are in a bad mood) are associated with heavier alcohol consumption (Cooper, Agocha, & Sheldon, 2000; Labouvie & Bates, 2002; Montgomery et al., 1993; Kairouz et al., 2002; Kuntsche et al., 2005).  Drinking motives are also predictive of alcohol-related problems. For instance, drinking to cope is strongly associated with negative alcohol-related consequences, such as neglecting responsibilities, passing out or fainting due to drinking, and experiencing interpersonal difficulties with family and friends (Chelsie et al., 2015; Collins, Thompson et al., 2018; Cooper, Frone, Russell, & Mudar, 1995; DiBello et al., 2018; Kuntsche et al., 2005; Mackinnon et al., 2014; McNally, Palfai, Levine, & Moore, 2003; Simons, Correia, & Carey, 2000; Windle & Windle, 1996; White & Labouvie, 1989). Further, enhancement motives have been shown to predict future alcohol-related problems (Chelsie et al., 2015; Cooper, 1994; Cooper et al., 2000; Cronin, 1997; Labouvie & Bates, 2002; Mackinnon et al., 2014; White, Anderson, Ray & Mun, 2016); for example, Mackinnon and colleagues (2014) found that enhancement motives prospectively predicted alcohol-related problems as measured by the Rutgers Alcohol Problem Index after a six-month follow-up period (RAPI; White and Labouvie, 1989). 

A review published by Kuntsche et al. in 2005 on the measurement of drinking motives, found that among 54 studies that used a multidimensional approach to examine drinking motives, there was a significant amount of heterogeneity in the instruments used. Across these 54 studies, 25 unique instruments were used, with between 10 and 40 items per scale. Kuntsche et al. (2005) also found that specific scale items used to indicate different drinking motive factors (i.e., coping, enhancement, conformity, and social) varied across studies, and this variation was directly related to conclusions that were drawn; for example, if the enhancement factor in one scale contained items such as “enjoying a party”, then enhancement motives were closely associated with moderate drinking, whereas if the enhancement factor contained items such as “drinking to get drunk”, then this motive was more closely associated with heavier drinking. This array of drinking motive questionnaires, and related issues regarding the classification of scale items within each questionnaire, makes generalizing results difficult. 

The data from this study will be useful in generating a more comprehensive and coherent measure of drinking motives. We hypothesize that a new factor structure may emerge that follows a similar structure to the initial motives theory put forth by Cox and Klinger (1988), but represents a more holistic representation of the latent variables that define drinking motives in young adults. Additionally, while the Drinking Motives Questionnaire – Revised (DMQ-R; Cooper, 1994) is the most highly cited tool currently used to assess drinking motives, it exists alongside many other assessment tools, as explained. As such, we will directly compare our newly developed drinking motives scale to the DMQ-R in predicting alcohol-related consequences and other alcohol-related behaviors. These analyses will test whether our new scale and corresponding factor structure may serve as an improvement over the current “gold standard” drinking motives scale in the literature.

At baseline, coping motives are predicted to be directly associated with alcohol-related consequences, and both social and enhancement motives may be linked to consequences indirectly through drinking behavior (Halim, Hasking, and Allen, 2012; Lee et al., 2007; Merrill, Wardell, & Read, 2014; Patrick, Lee, & Larimer, 2011). We also predict that this study will replicate previous findings when participants are followed over a 6-month period, where enhancement motives are expected to be the strongest predictor of changes in alcohol use, coping motives are expected to be most predictive of changes in alcohol-related consequences, and social motives may be prospectively linked to changes in both alcohol use and related outcomes through direct and indirect pathways, respectively (Corbin, Iwamoto, and Fromme, 2010; Crutzen, Kuntsche, & Shelleman-Offermans, 2013; Foster and Neighbors, 2013; Merrill, Wardell, & Read, 2014). Further, it is expected that conformity motives will be minimally predictive in measuring drinking behavior over time (Merrill and Read, 2010; Patrick et al., 2011). Overall, this study will help to improve the measurement of drinking motives, which will enable clinicians and researchers alike to better develop preventative and reactive treatment plans based on the evaluation of drinking motives.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name: Evaluation of Predictive Qualities of Drinking Motives in Relation to Alcohol-Related Problems: The Development of a Novel Psychometric Questionnaire to Measure Drinking Motivations
registration_responses.other:
Several individual difference variables will be assessed. These variables include social variables (e.g., social anxiety via the Social Interaction and Anxiety Scale [SIAS]; Mattick and Clark, 1998); personality variables (e.g., The Neuroticism-Extraversion-Openness Five Factor Inventory-Revised version 3 [NEO-60; Costa & McCrae, 1992], and the Personality Inventory for DSM-5 – Brief Form [PID-5-BF; Krueger, Derringer, Markon, Watson, & Skodol; 2013]; depression symptoms (e.g., the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 [PHQ-9; Kroenke, Spitzer, & Williams, 2001]; and general anxiety symptoms (e.g., the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 questionnaire [GAD-7; Spitzer, Kroenke, Williams, & Lowe, 2006]. 

Data for this study has been collected through a Qualtrics panel. Baseline data has been made available to researchers prior to when this preregistration was completed; 6 month follow-up data collection is ongoing.
registration_responses.sample: Given the large number of items we anticipated including in the factor analyses (N = 205), and given prior experience and relevant research as indicated by the literature, we decided that approximately 1000 participants were needed to measure drinking motives and perform hierarchical factor analyses to determine specific factors that each motive fits into, as well as accurately track changes in drinking behavior and alcohol-related problems over a six-month follow-up period.
registration_responses.analyses:
Primary analysis for this study will consist of Exploratory Hierarchical Factor Analysis utilizing the “Bassackwards” method (Goldberg, 2006) to find the appropriate factor structure for the new drinking motives questionnaire. This method is a top-down approach to exploratory factor analysis that first extracts one principle factor from a data set, and then two are extracted and rotated, then three, and so on until there is a factor that no variable has its highest factor (Goldberg, 2006). Horn’s Parallel Analysis will first be run to determine the maximum number of factors that should be considered. Factors will be extracted via principle axis factoring with a direct oblimin rotation, since all motives to consume alcohol are assumed to be correlated with each other. 

Multiple linear regression analyses will be used with both the newly developed drinking motives scale and the Drinking Motives Questionnaire-Revised (DMQ-R; Cooper, 1994) as the continuous predictor variables and pertinent alcohol-related outcomes (i.e., AUDIT scores, YAACQ-B scores, quantity and frequency of alcohol consumption) will serve as the continuous outcome variables. Covariates at baseline will include gender, age, ethnicity, and education level. Baseline drinking behavior and problems will be included as covariates in the 6-month follow-up analyses in order to test whether drinking motives at baseline predict changes in drinking behavior and problems over follow-up.
registration_responses.dependent:
The key dependent variables will be alcohol problems and alcohol-related behaviors. These will be measured through several different questionnaires.

Alcohol problems will be measured through the administration of the Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test (AUDIT; Saunders, Aasland, Babor, De la Fuente, & Grant, 1993), and the Brief Young Adult Alcohol Consequences Questionnaire (B-YAACQ; Kahler, Strong, & Read, 2005). The AUDIT is designed to assess problematic alcohol use and related behavior. The B-YAACQ assesses negative consequences associated with alcohol use. 

Alcohol-related behaviors will be assessed with the Drinking Refusal Self-Efficacy Questionnaire – Revised (DRSEQ-R; Oei, Hasking, & Young, 2005). The DRSEQ-R assesses a person’s belief in their ability to resist alcohol in social pressure situations, emotional relief situations, and opportunistic situations. Past year and past month alcohol use quantity and frequency, as well as frequency of binge drinking were measured using the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism’s (NIAAA) alcohol consumption question set (NIAAA, 2003). Age of first drink, age of first intoxication, past year maximum drink quantity during one occasion, and frequency of drinking that maximum amount were also assessed (NIAAA, 2003). Solitary drinking was also measured by asking participants to indicate the percentage of time (on a 0 – 100% scale) their drinking occurred while alone (i.e., “without anyone else around”) versus with others since they began drinking (Creswell et al., 2014; Creswell et al., 2015, Skrzynski et al., 2018).
registration_responses.conditions: This is a correlational study, so participants will not be assigned to conditions. Participants’ motivations to consume alcohol will be assessed via the administration of an experimenter-created psychometric scale consisting of 205 unique items. 197 Items for this scale were drawn from previously used scales cited by Kuntsche et al. in 2005. Eight additional items were adapted from the Brief Fear of Negative Evaluation Scale (Leary, 1983; Rodebaugh et. al., 2004). Participants were presented with the following instructions before completing the questionnaire: “Listed below are reasons people might be inclined to drink alcoholic beverages.  Using the five-point scale below, decide how frequently your own drinking is motivated by each of the reasons listed.” The wording of all items was modified from their original version to fit the root “You drink…”.  Relative frequency of drinking in response to each item was rated on a 5-Point Likert Scale (1 = Almost Never/Never, 2 = Some of the time, 3 = Half of the time, 4 = Most of the time, 5 = Almost Always/Always). To ensure that response biases and participant fatigue did not factor into responses, items were randomized in their presentation.
registration_responses.hypothesis:

We will test the concurrent and predictive validity of the scale by examining its association to the Drinking Motives Questionnaire-Revised (DMQ-R; Cooper, 1994) at baseline and related behavioral outcomes (e.g., alcohol use and problems) at baseline and 6-month follow-up (controlling for baseline alcohol use and problems).
